# _Memphis Belle_ (aircraft)

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to navigation Jump to search

This article is about the aircraft. For other uses, including films about the
aircraft, see [Memphis Belle](/wiki/Memphis_Belle_\(disambiguation\) "Memphis
Belle \(disambiguation\)").

_Memphis Belle_  
---  
[![Memphis
Belle.jpg](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2a/Memphis_Belle.jpg/300px-
Memphis_Belle.jpg)](/wiki/File:Memphis_Belle.jpg)  
Boeing B-17F-10-BO Flying Fortress, AAF Ser. No. 41-24485, _Memphis Belle_ ,
324th Bomb Squadron, [91st Bomb Group](/wiki/91st_Bomb_Group "91st Bomb
Group"), 9 June 1943  
Type  | [Boeing B-17F Flying Fortress](/wiki/Boeing_B-17_Flying_Fortress "Boeing B-17 Flying Fortress")  
Manufacturer  | [Boeing Aircraft Company](/wiki/Boeing "Boeing")  
Construction number | 3470[1]  
Serial  | 41-24485   
Radio code  | DF-A   
Owners and operators | [United States Army Air Forces](/wiki/United_States_Army_Air_Forces "United States Army Air Forces")  
Fate  | On display   
Preserved at | [National Museum of the United States Air Force](/wiki/National_Museum_of_the_United_States_Air_Force "National Museum of the United States Air Force")  
  
_**Memphis Belle**_ is a [Boeing B-17F Flying
Fortress](/wiki/Boeing_B-17_Flying_Fortress "Boeing B-17 Flying Fortress")
used during the [Second World War](/wiki/Second_World_War "Second World War")
that inspired the making of two motion pictures: a 1944 [documentary
film](/wiki/Documentary_film "Documentary film"), _[Memphis Belle: A Story of
a Flying Fortress](/wiki/Memphis_Belle:_A_Story_of_a_Flying_Fortress "Memphis
Belle: A Story of a Flying Fortress")_ , and a 1990
[Hollywood](/wiki/Hollywood "Hollywood") feature film, _[Memphis
Belle](/wiki/Memphis_Belle_\(film\) "Memphis Belle \(film\)")_. The aircraft
was one of the first [United States Army Air
Forces](/wiki/United_States_Army_Air_Forces "United States Army Air Forces")
B-17 heavy bombers to complete 25 combat missions. The aircraft and crew then
returned to the United States to sell [war bonds](/wiki/War_bonds "War
bonds").[2] In 2005, restoration began on the aircraft at the [National Museum
of the United States Air
Force](/wiki/National_Museum_of_the_United_States_Air_Force "National Museum
of the United States Air Force") at [Wright-Patterson AFB](/wiki/Wright-
Patterson_AFB "Wright-Patterson AFB") in [Dayton, Ohio](/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio
"Dayton, Ohio") where, from May 2018, it is on display.[3][4]

##
Crew[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Memphis_Belle_\(aircraft\)&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Crew")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1f/MemphisBelle_crew_USAF.jpg/220px-
MemphisBelle_crew_USAF.jpg)](/wiki/File:MemphisBelle_crew_USAF.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:MemphisBelle_crew_USAF.jpg "Enlarge")

Crew of the _Memphis Belle_.They are, left to right: Tech. Sgt. Harold P. Loch
of Green Bay, Wis., top turret gunner; Staff Sgt. Cecil H. Scott of Altoona,
Penn., ball turret gunner; Tech. Sgt. Robert J, Hanson of Walla Walla, Wash.,

## Combat
history[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Memphis_Belle_\(aircraft\)&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Combat history")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/49/The_crew_of_the_B-17_%22Memphis_Belle%22.jpg/220px-
The_crew_of_the_B-17_%22Memphis_Belle%22.jpg)](/wiki/File:The_crew_of_the_B-17_%22Memphis_Belle%22.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:The_crew_of_the_B-17_%22Memphis_Belle%22.jpg "Enlarge")

The crew back from their 25th operational mission. All were awarded the
[Distinguished Flying
Cross](/wiki/Distinguished_Flying_Cross_\(United_States\) "Distinguished
Flying Cross \(United States\)") and the [Air Medal](/wiki/Air_Medal "Air
Medal").

The _Memphis Belle_ , a [Boeing](/wiki/Boeing "Boeing")-built B-17F-10-BO,
manufacturer's serial number 3470, USAAC Serial No. 41-24485, was added to the
USAAF inventory on 15 July 1942,[6] and delivered in September 1942 to the
[91st Bombardment Group](/wiki/91st_Bombardment_Group "91st Bombardment
Group") at [Dow Field](/wiki/Bangor_International_Airport "Bangor
International Airport"), [Bangor, Maine](/wiki/Bangor,_Maine "Bangor,
Maine").[7] She deployed to [Prestwick](/wiki/Glasgow_Prestwick_Airport
"Glasgow Prestwick Airport"), [Scotland](/wiki/Scotland "Scotland"), on 30
September 1942, moving to a temporary base at [RAF
Kimbolton](/wiki/RAF_Kimbolton "RAF Kimbolton") on 1 October, and then finally
to her permanent base at [RAF Bassingbourn](/wiki/RAF_Bassingbourn "RAF
Bassingbourn"), [England](/wiki/England "England"), on 14 October.[7] Each
side of the fuselage bore the [unit and aircraft identification
markings](/wiki/USAAF_unit_identification_aircraft_markings "USAAF unit
identification aircraft markings") of a B-17 of the 324th Bomb Squadron
(Heavy); the squadron code "DF" and individual aircraft letter "A."[6][8]

Captain [Robert K. Morgan](/wiki/Robert_K._Morgan "Robert K. Morgan")'s crew
flew 29 combat missions with the 324th Bomb Squadron, all but four in the
_Memphis Belle_. The aircraft's 25 combat missions, which included eight
German aircraft shot down by her crew, were:

  * 7 November 1942 – [Brest, France](/wiki/Brest,_France "Brest, France")[9][N 1]
  * 9 November 1942 – [St. Nazaire](/wiki/St._Nazaire "St. Nazaire"), France [9]
  * 17 November 1942 – St. Nazaire, France[9]
  * 6 December 1942 – [Lille](/wiki/Lille "Lille"), France[9]
  * 20 December 1942* – [Romilly-sur-Seine](/wiki/Romilly-sur-Seine "Romilly-sur-Seine"), [France](/wiki/France "France") [9][10][11]
  * 30 December 1942 – [Lorient](/wiki/Lorient "Lorient"), France (flown by Lt. James A. Verinis)
  * 3 January 1943 – St. Nazaire, France[9]
  * 13 January 1943 – Lille, France[9]
  * 23 January 1943 – Lorient, France[9]
  * 14 February 1943 – [Hamm](/wiki/Hamm "Hamm"), [Germany](/wiki/Germany "Germany")[9]
  * 16 February 1943 – St. Nazaire, France[9]
  * 27 February 1943* – Brest, France[9][N 2]
  * 6 March 1943 – Lorient, France[9]
  * 12 March 1943 – [Rouen](/wiki/Rouen "Rouen"), France[9]
  * 13 March 1943 – [Abbeville](/wiki/Abbeville "Abbeville"), France [9]
  * 22 March 1943 – [Wilhelmshaven](/wiki/Wilhelmshaven "Wilhelmshaven"), Germany [9]
  * 28 March 1943 – Rouen, France[9]
  * 31 March 1943 – [Rotterdam](/wiki/Rotterdam "Rotterdam"), [Netherlands](/wiki/Netherlands "Netherlands") [11][13][14]
  * 16 April 1943 – Lorient, France[9]
  * 17 April 1943 – [Bremen](/wiki/Bremen "Bremen"), Germany [9]
  * 1 May 1943 – St. Nazaire, France[9]
  * 13 May 1943 – [Meaulte](/wiki/Meaulte "Meaulte"), France (flown by Lt. C.L. Anderson)
  * 14 May 1943 – [Kiel](/wiki/Kiel "Kiel"), Germany (flown by Lt. John H. Miller)
  * 15 May 1943 – Wilhelmshaven, Germany[9]
  * 17 May 1943 – Lorient, France[9]
  * 19 May 1943* – Kiel, Germany (flown by Lt. Anderson) [N 3]

* Sources disagree on which two of these three missions the _Memphis Belle_ received mission credits for. 

Morgan's crew completed the following missions in B-17s other than the
_Memphis Belle_ :

  * 4 February 1943 – [Emden](/wiki/Emden "Emden"), Germany (in B-17 DF-H 41-24515 _Jersey Bounce_)[16]
  * 26 February 1943 – Wilhelmshaven, Germany (in B-17 41-24515)[17]
  * 5 April 1943 – [Antwerp](/wiki/Antwerp "Antwerp"), [Belgium](/wiki/Belgium "Belgium") (in B-17 41-24480 _Bad Penny_)[17]
  * 4 May 1943 – Antwerp, Belgium (in B-17 41-24527, _The Great Speckled Bird_)[18]

The aircraft was then flown back to the United States on 8 June 1943, by a
composite crew chosen by the [Eighth Air Force](/wiki/Eighth_Air_Force "Eighth
Air Force") from those who had flown combat aboard, led by Capt. Morgan, for a
31-city [war bond](/wiki/War_bond "War bond") tour. Morgan's original co-pilot
was Capt. James A. Verinis, who himself piloted the _Memphis Belle_ for one
mission. Verinis was promoted to aircraft commander of another B-17 for his
final 16 missions and finished his tour on 13 May. He rejoined Morgan's crew
as co-pilot for the flight back to the United States.

The B-17 _Hell 's Angels_ (41-24577) of the 303rd Bomb Group completed 25
combat missions on 13 May 1943, becoming the first B-17 to complete the feat,
one week before the _Memphis Belle_.[19][20]

## Source of the
name[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Memphis_Belle_\(aircraft\)&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Source of the name")]

The aircraft was named after pilot Robert K Morgan's sweetheart, Margaret
Polk, a resident of [Memphis, Tennessee](/wiki/Memphis,_Tennessee "Memphis,
Tennessee"). Morgan originally intended to call the aircraft _Little One_ ,
which was his pet name for her, but after Morgan and copilot Jim Verinis saw
the movie _[Lady for a Night](/wiki/Lady_for_a_Night "Lady for a Night")_ , in
which the leading character owns a [riverboat](/wiki/Riverboat "Riverboat")
named the _Memphis Belle_ , he proposed that name to his crew.[N 4] Morgan
then contacted [George Petty](/wiki/George_Petty "George Petty") at the
offices of _[Esquire](/wiki/Esquire_\(magazine\) "Esquire \(magazine\)")_
magazine and asked him for a [pinup](/wiki/Pinup "Pinup") drawing to go with
the name, which Petty supplied from the magazine's April 1941 issue.[22]

The 91st's group artist, Corporal [Tony Starcer](/wiki/Tony_Starcer "Tony
Starcer"), copied the [Petty girl](/wiki/George_Petty "George Petty") as art
on both sides of the forward fuselage, depicting her suit in blue on the
aircraft's port side and in red on the starboard. The [nose
art](/wiki/Nose_art "Nose art") later included 25 bomb shapes, one for each
mission credit, and eight [swastika](/wiki/Swastikas "Swastikas") designs, one
for each German aircraft claimed shot down by the crew. Station and crew names
were stenciled below station windows on the aircraft after her tour of duty
was completed.

## Postwar
history[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Memphis_Belle_\(aircraft\)&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Postwar history")]

In his memoirs, Morgan claimed that during his publicity tour he flew the B-17
between the [Buncombe County](/wiki/Buncombe_County "Buncombe County")
Courthouse and the City Hall of [Asheville, North
Carolina](/wiki/Asheville,_North_Carolina "Asheville, North Carolina"), his
home town. Morgan wrote that after leaving a local airport he decided to buzz
the town, telling his copilot, Captain Verinis, "I think we'll just drive up
over the city and give them a little goodbye salute." Morgan turned the bomber
down Patton Avenue, a main thoroughfare, toward downtown Asheville. When he
observed the courthouse and the city hall (two tall buildings that are only
about 50 ft (20 m) apart) dead ahead, he lowered his left wing in a 60 degree
bank and flew between the structures. He wrote that the city hall housed an
AAF weather detachment whose commanding officer allegedly complained
immediately to the [Pentagon](/wiki/The_Pentagon "The Pentagon"), but was
advised by a duty officer that "Major Morgan...has been given permission to
buzz by General [Henry "Hap" Arnold](/wiki/Henry_H._Arnold "Henry H.
Arnold")."[23]

### Display in
Memphis[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Memphis_Belle_\(aircraft\)&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Display in Memphis")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/99/Question_book-
new.svg/50px-Question_book-new.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Question_book-new.svg)|
This section **does not[cite](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources "Wikipedia:Citing
sources") any [sources](/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability
"Wikipedia:Verifiability")**. Please help [improve this
section](//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Memphis_Belle_\(aircraft\)&action=edit)
by [adding citations to reliable
sources](/wiki/Help:Introduction_to_referencing_with_Wiki_Markup/1
"Help:Introduction to referencing with Wiki Markup/1"). Unsourced material may
be challenged and [removed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability#Burden_of_evidence
"Wikipedia:Verifiability"). _(March 2018)__([Learn how and when to remove this
template message](/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal "Help:Maintenance
template removal"))_  
---|---  
  
After the war, the _Memphis Belle_ was saved from reclamation at [Altus Air
Force Base](/wiki/Altus_Air_Force_Base "Altus Air Force Base"), Oklahoma where
she had been consigned since 1 August 1945, by the efforts of the mayor of
[Memphis](/wiki/Memphis,_Tennessee "Memphis, Tennessee"), [Walter
Chandler](/wiki/Walter_Chandler "Walter Chandler"). The city of Memphis bought
the B-17 for US$350 (equivalent to $4,758 in 2017).[24][25] She was flown to
Memphis in July 1946 and stored until the summer of 1949 when she was placed
on display at the [National Guard](/wiki/United_States_National_Guard "United
States National Guard") armory near the city's fairgrounds. She sat out-of-
doors into the 1980s, slowly deteriorating from weather and
[vandalism](/wiki/Vandalism "Vandalism"). Souvenir hunters removed almost all
of the interior components. Eventually no instruments were left in the
cockpit, and virtually every removable piece of the aircraft's interior had
been scavenged, often severing the aircraft's wiring and control cables in the
process.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4a/Memphis_Bell_on_War_Bond_tour_at_Patterson_Field.jpg/220px-
Memphis_Bell_on_War_Bond_tour_at_Patterson_Field.jpg)](/wiki/File:Memphis_Bell_on_War_Bond_tour_at_Patterson_Field.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Memphis_Bell_on_War_Bond_tour_at_Patterson_Field.jpg "Enlarge")

The _Memphis Belle_ on a [War Bond](/wiki/War_Bond "War Bond") campaign at
[Patterson Field](/wiki/Wright-Patterson_Air_Force_Base "Wright-Patterson Air
Force Base") during World War II.

In the early 1970s, another mayor had donated the historic aircraft back to
the Air Force, but they allowed her to remain in
[Memphis](/wiki/Memphis,_Tennessee "Memphis, Tennessee") contingent on her
being maintained. Efforts by the locally organized _Memphis Belle_ Memorial
Association, Inc. (MBMA) saw the aircraft moved to [Mud
Island](/wiki/Mud_Island,_Memphis "Mud Island, Memphis") in the [Mississippi
River](/wiki/Mississippi_River "Mississippi River") in 1987 for display in a
new pavilion with large tarp cover.[25] She was still open to the elements,
however, and prone to weathering. Pigeons would also nest inside the tarp and
droppings were constantly needing removal from the B-17. Dissatisfaction with
the site led to efforts to create a new museum facility in [Shelby
County](/wiki/Shelby_County,_Tennessee "Shelby County, Tennessee"). In the
summer of 2003 the _Belle_ was disassembled and moved to a restoration
facility at the former [Naval Air Station
Memphis](/wiki/Naval_Air_Station_Memphis "Naval Air Station Memphis") in
[Millington, Tennessee](/wiki/Millington,_Tennessee "Millington, Tennessee")
for work. In September 2004, however, the [National Museum of the United
States Air Force](/wiki/National_Museum_of_the_United_States_Air_Force
"National Museum of the United States Air Force"), apparently tiring of the
ups and downs of the city's attempts to preserve the aircraft, indicated that
they wanted her back for restoration and eventual display at the museum at
[Wright-Patterson AFB](/wiki/Wright-Patterson_AFB "Wright-Patterson AFB") near
[Dayton, Ohio](/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio "Dayton, Ohio"). _The Memphis Belle- The
Final Chapter in Memphis_ , a documentary film by Ken Axmaker, Jr., focuses on
the history of the _Belle_ in Memphis and emphasizes the final days and the
volunteers who tried to keep one of the most famous aircraft in the world and
another Memphis icon from disappearing.

### Move to
Dayton[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Memphis_Belle_\(aircraft\)&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Move to Dayton")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/03/Memphis_Belle_NMUSAF_2011-12.jpg/220px-
Memphis_Belle_NMUSAF_2011-12.jpg)](/wiki/File:Memphis_Belle_NMUSAF_2011-12.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Memphis_Belle_NMUSAF_2011-12.jpg "Enlarge")

_Memphis Belle_ during refurbishment in 2011.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/Memphis_Belle_-_180514-F-IO108-003.jpg/220px-
Memphis_Belle_-_180514-F-IO108-003.jpg)](/wiki/File:Memphis_Belle_-_180514-F-IO108-003.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Memphis_Belle_-_180514-F-IO108-003.jpg "Enlarge")

_Memphis Belle_ after refurbishment was completed in 2018.

On 30 August 2005, the MBMA announced that a consultant that they hired
determined that the MBMA would not be able to raise enough money to restore
the _Belle_ and otherwise fulfill the Air Force's requirements to keep
possession of the aircraft. They announced plans to return the aircraft to the
[National Museum of the United States Air
Force](/wiki/National_Museum_of_the_United_States_Air_Force "National Museum
of the United States Air Force") at [Wright-Patterson AFB](/wiki/Wright-
Patterson_AFB "Wright-Patterson AFB") near [Dayton, Ohio](/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio
"Dayton, Ohio"), after a final exhibition at an airshow in [Millington,
Tennessee](/wiki/Millington,_Tennessee "Millington, Tennessee") from 30
September–2 October 2005. The _Belle_ arrived safely at the museum in mid-
October 2005 and was placed in one of the Museum's restoration hangars.

The Museum placed restoration of _Memphis Belle_ near the top of its
priorities. In the magazine _Friends Journal_ of the museum's foundation,
Major General [Charles D. Metcalf](/wiki/Charles_D._Metcalf "Charles D.
Metcalf"), USAF (Ret), then the director of the museum, stated that it might
take eight to 10 years to fully restore the aircraft.

By the spring of 2009, considerable preparatory work had been accomplished,
but the fuselage and wings were still disassembled.[26]

After stripping the paint from the aft fuselage of the aircraft, hundreds of
names and personal messages were found scratched in the aluminum skin. It
turned out that, during the aircraft's war bond tour, people were allowed to
leave their mark there.

In May 2017 the museum announced the goal of completing the restoration and
putting the _Memphis Belle_ on display by May 17, 2018, the 75th anniversary
of the plane's 25th mission.[27] On March 19, 2018 the _Memphis Belle_ was
moved into the WWII Gallery at the National Museum of the United States Air
Force, and was officially unveiled May 17, 2018.[4]

## _Memphis Belle_ film
(1990)[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Memphis_Belle_\(aircraft\)&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Memphis Belle film \(1990\)")]

Main article: [Memphis Belle (film)](/wiki/Memphis_Belle_\(film\) "Memphis
Belle \(film\)")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a0/Memphisbellenose.jpg/220px-
Memphisbellenose.jpg)](/wiki/File:Memphisbellenose.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Memphisbellenose.jpg "Enlarge")

The B-17 that portrayed _Memphis Belle_ in the 1990 film at the Joint Service
Open House at Andrews Air Force Base in 2008.

Five airworthy B-17s were used in the filming of the 1990 British-American war
drama film _[Memphis Belle](/wiki/Memphis_Belle_\(film\) "Memphis Belle
\(film\)")_ , two from the US (N-17W – now on display in Seattle and _Movie
Memphis Belle_ 44-83546), B-17G _[Sally B](/wiki/Sally_B "Sally B")_ from the
UK and two French geographic survey B-17Gs, one of which crashed on take-off
near the end of filming.

The B-17Gs had some sections converted into a B-17F configuration for the
film. A former civilian firebomber, B-17G-85-DL, AAC Serial No. 44-83546, FAA
registered N3703G, was converted by installing a Sperry top turret, early-
style tail gunner's compartment and waist gunner's positions, and omitting the
chin turret. After appearing in the film, this plane continues to make air
show appearances as _Movie Memphis Belle_ in that configuration. Originally
painted with the Warner Brothers movie version of the nose art and markings,
the B-17 (owned by [restaurateur](/wiki/Restaurateur "Restaurateur") [David
Tallichet](/wiki/David_Tallichet "David Tallichet") until his death in 2007)
now carries the historic markings found on the actual _Memphis Belle_. That
aircraft is currently leased by the [National Warplane
Museum](/wiki/National_Warplane_Museum "National Warplane Museum") in
[Geneseo, New York](/wiki/Geneseo,_New_York "Geneseo, New York") and provides
historical flight experiences to the public.[28]

The _Sally B_ , used in film, is the last airworthy B-17 in the United Kingdom
and is based at the [Imperial War Museum,
Duxford](/wiki/Imperial_War_Museum_Duxford "Imperial War Museum Duxford"). She
is part of the USAAC World War II Memorial Flight and makes dozens of
appearances across the United Kingdom and Northern Europe. She is maintained
and run by volunteers, relying solely upon donations.

In addition to the airworthy B-17s, others were used as planes visible at the
airbase in the film, but not as the _Memphis Belle_. One example, B-17F-70-BO,
Serial number 42-29782, is located at the [Museum of
Flight](/wiki/Museum_of_Flight "Museum of Flight"), Seattle, WA. _Boeing Bee_
has been completely restored and is potentially airworthy once again.

## Other aircraft named _Memphis
Belle_[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Memphis_Belle_\(aircraft\)&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: Other aircraft named Memphis Belle")]

  * A [Republic F-105D Thunderchief](/wiki/Republic_F-105_Thunderchief "Republic F-105 Thunderchief") (AF Ser. No. 60-0504) from [357th Tactical Fighter Squadron](/wiki/357th_Tactical_Fighter_Squadron "357th Tactical Fighter Squadron") of the [355th Tactical Fighter Wing](/wiki/355th_Tactical_Fighter_Wing "355th Tactical Fighter Wing") based at [Takhli Royal Thai Air Base](/wiki/Takhli_Royal_Thai_Air_Base "Takhli Royal Thai Air Base") during the [Vietnam War](/wiki/Vietnam_War "Vietnam War") was named _**Memphis Belle II**_ in honor of the original B-17F. The aircraft claimed two [MiG-17](/wiki/Mikoyan-Gurevich_MiG-17 "Mikoyan-Gurevich MiG-17") kills in addition to numerous bombing missions, and was the last F-105 to fly. It is currently preserved at the [National Museum of the United States Air Force](/wiki/National_Museum_of_the_United_States_Air_Force "National Museum of the United States Air Force") at [Wright-Patterson Air Force Base](/wiki/Wright-Patterson_Air_Force_Base "Wright-Patterson Air Force Base") near [Dayton, Ohio](/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio "Dayton, Ohio"). She was donated in April 1990.[29]
  * A [Rockwell B-1B Lancer](/wiki/Rockwell_B-1_Lancer "Rockwell B-1 Lancer") (AF Ser. No. 86-0133) was named _**Memphis Belle**_. In 1996, Colonel [Robert K. Morgan](/wiki/Robert_K._Morgan "Robert K. Morgan"), pilot of the original _**Memphis Belle**_ , received the opportunity to fly in this aircraft, while she served with the [Georgia Air National Guard](/wiki/Georgia_Air_National_Guard "Georgia Air National Guard")'s [116th Bomb Wing](/wiki/116th_Air_Control_Wing "116th Air Control Wing") at [Robins AFB](/wiki/Robins_AFB "Robins AFB"), Georgia.[30]
  * A [General Dynamics FB-111A Aardvark](/wiki/General_Dynamics_F-111_Aardvark "General Dynamics F-111 Aardvark") (AF Ser. No. 68-0267) was also nicknamed _**Memphis Belle II**_ for a period during the 1980s. She is currently located at the [Strategic Air Command Museum](/wiki/Strategic_Air_Command_Museum "Strategic Air Command Museum"), located in Ashland, Nebraska.[31]
  * Two [Boeing B-52 Stratofortresses](/wiki/Boeing_B-52_Stratofortress "Boeing B-52 Stratofortress") have carried the name _**Memphis Belle**_ B-52G (AF Ser. No. 59-2594) was named _**Memphis Belle III**_ and took part in the 1991 [Gulf War](/wiki/Gulf_War "Gulf War"). That aircraft was retired from active service as the B-52G was phased out of USAF service and sent to the [AMARC](/wiki/Aerospace_Maintenance_and_Regeneration_Center "Aerospace Maintenance and Regeneration Center") at [Davis-Monthan AFB](/wiki/Davis-Monthan_AFB "Davis-Monthan AFB"), Arizona in October, 1992. The first B-52H (AF Ser. No. 60-0001) was named _**Memphis Belle IV**_ and is currently assigned to the [2nd Bomb Wing](/wiki/2nd_Bomb_Wing "2nd Bomb Wing") at [Barksdale Air Force Base](/wiki/Barksdale_Air_Force_Base "Barksdale Air Force Base"), Louisiana, having seen action in both Iraq and Afghanistan in support of Operations [Iraqi Freedom](/wiki/Iraqi_Freedom "Iraqi Freedom") and [Enduring Freedom](/wiki/Enduring_Freedom "Enduring Freedom").[32]
  * A McDonnell Douglas F-15E (AF Ser. No 89-0485) from the 336th Fighter Squadron, 4th Fighter Wing, flew with the nose art "Memphis Belle III" during Operation Iraqi Freedom in 2003.
  * A [Lockheed C-141 Starlifter](/wiki/Lockheed_C-141_Starlifter "Lockheed C-141 Starlifter") (AF Ser. No 67-0024) became the _**Memphis Belle V**_. She was transferred to the AMARC inventory upon the retirement of all C-141s from active service in the [U.S. Air Force](/wiki/U.S._Air_Force "U.S. Air Force"), to include the [Air Force Reserve](/wiki/Air_Force_Reserve "Air Force Reserve") and the [Air National Guard](/wiki/Air_National_Guard "Air National Guard").[33]
  * A [Lockheed C-5 Galaxy](/wiki/Lockheed_C-5_Galaxy "Lockheed C-5 Galaxy") (AF Ser. No. 69-0025) was named the _**Memphis Belle X**_ was assigned to the [164th Airlift Wing](/wiki/164th_Airlift_Wing "164th Airlift Wing") of the [Tennessee Air National Guard](/wiki/Tennessee_Air_National_Guard "Tennessee Air National Guard") at [Memphis Air National Guard Base](/w/index.php?title=Memphis_Air_National_Guard_Base&action=edit&redlink=1 "Memphis Air National Guard Base \(page does not exist\)").[34]
  * A [Boeing C-17 Globemaster III](/wiki/Boeing_C-17_Globemaster_III "Boeing C-17 Globemaster III") (AF Ser. No. 93-0600) is named the _**Memphis Belle XI**_ assigned currently to the [164th Airlift Wing](/wiki/164th_Airlift_Wing "164th Airlift Wing") of the [Tennessee Air National Guard](/wiki/Tennessee_Air_National_Guard "Tennessee Air National Guard") at [Memphis Air National Guard Base](/w/index.php?title=Memphis_Air_National_Guard_Base&action=edit&redlink=1 "Memphis Air National Guard Base \(page does not exist\)").
  * [Pinnacle Airlines](/wiki/Pinnacle_Airlines "Pinnacle Airlines")' first [Bombardier CRJ](/wiki/Bombardier_CRJ200 "Bombardier CRJ200") (N8390A) is named _**Spirit of Memphis Belle**_.[35]

qa.question: was the memphis belle the first to complete 25 missions

nq_5196_29.Query Analysis: The query asks whether the Memphis Belle was the first aircraft to complete 25 missions.
nq_5196_29.Answer Analysis: The answer indicates that the Memphis Belle was 'one of the first' to complete 25 missions, suggesting it was not the absolute first but among the early ones.
nq_5196_29.Document Content Analysis: The document discusses various missions and accounts related to the Memphis Belle, including discrepancies in mission records and statements about the aircraft's activities after a certain date. It mentions that all references except one show a particular mission as the 25th for the Memphis Belle.
nq_5196_29.Document and Query Keywords Matching: The document mentions 'Memphis Belle' and references to its 25th mission.
nq_5196_29.Document and Answer Keywords Matching: The document does not explicitly state 'one of the first', but it implies multiple accounts and missions, which can infer that it was not the absolute first.
nq_5196_29.Key Information Matching: The document provides information about the 25th mission of the Memphis Belle and discrepancies in records, which is key to understanding its position among other aircraft in completing 25 missions.
nq_5196_29.Can the Document Answer the Query: No, the document does not directly state whether the Memphis Belle was the first to complete 25 missions.
